posts.name: Grant Watson
posts.cooked:
Screenshot 2025-06-18 at 9.08.56 PM 1357×1242 121 KB Screenshot 2025-06-18 at 9.03.43 PM 1476×1361 130 KB Team 190 “Gompei and The HERD” is proud to release the CAD for both of our competing 2025 robots, StackUp and Redundancy!

Screenshot 2025-06-18 at 9.08.56 PM 1357×1242 121 KB

Screenshot 2025-06-18 at 9.08.56 PM 1357×1242 121 KB

Screenshot 2025-06-18 at 9.03.43 PM 1476×1361 130 KB

Onshape FRC 190, 2025 V1 StackUp

Onshape FRC 190, 2025 V1 StackUp

Onshape FRC 190, 2025 V2 Redundancy

Onshape FRC 190, 2025 V2 Redundancy

Please feel free to ask any questions

Loved the robot, one of my favorites to watch all season. Few questions:

The star wheels on V2’s outtake, do they help with the L4 by flipping the coral up as it leaves?

What was the thought process behind closing the ramp to straighten/hold on to the coral instead of running a belt to power the coral through

Where did you guys source your sensor for the ramp? It’s very unique and the first I’ve seen.

Why did your team opt to use a 6 motor elevator at the start? (And how much overkill was it?)

Where did the most of the weight savings come from for the algae mechanisms

What manufacturing capabilities do you have? (CNC’s, routers) Would like to know more about your setup!

When did the rebuild/planning process start?

Where did the name “Gompei and the HERD” come from?

Congrats on a great season!

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
For number 3, we used this photoelectric sensor: Allen-Bradley 42EF-D1MNAK-A2 :: RIGHTSIGHT :: Rexel USA

We had it from a previous season. Unfortunately I believe it’s been discontinued.

posts.name: Anshu Adiga
posts.cooked:
We do have belts to guide the coral but the funnel closing just secures it more when the robot is moving in and out of the station area very quickly. This also came in handy for V2 when we would have an algae and wanted to just store the coral (passively) in the funnel.

We wanted acceleration (from stow to L4 as fast as possible). In the end (even for V1) we went with 4 motors because the difference between 6 and 4 would have been around 20 ms.

We got weight from every part possible, elevator, end effector, funnel, and even the drive chassis

posts.name: Mactar Gueye
posts.cooked:
I have really loved the 190 climber since seeing it at the week zero event and have tried to replicate it before

Taking a look at it could you possibly explain how it deploys, I’d assume it has to do with the blue circle in this image

image 930×824 117 KB

image 930×824 117 KB

image 930×824 117 KB

I was also wondering what the yellow circle does, is it a pulley for the rope?

Finally, I was wondering what your rope path looked like and how the grappling hook is attached to the entire assembly.

Sorry for the slew of questions around the climber.

Congratulations on your success in this season in district and champs!

posts.name: Alex Fenwick
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the questions!

#1 Yep, originally we didn’t have them and found that sometimes we weren’t getting the flip up motion that we wanted, especially when slightly too low. The star wheel helped grab the lip of the coral and flip it onto L4.

#2 Adding onto what @Anshu mentioned, we also went with the clapping funnel as it helps manipulate the coral as well as gets it out of the way for the climb. We already needed the DOF to move the funnel, might as well use it to help intake.

#6 We are very fortunate to have a quite a decked out shop that’s brand new as of last year, the standouts are:

Haas VF4SS Mill

Bridgeport Mill

2 Lathes

ShopSabre Router

Laser Cutter

Powder cutting booth and oven

Some Bambus, a couple Form 2s, ,and a Markforged ShopSabre 1200×1600 365 KB Haas 1177×717 108 KB

ShopSabre 1200×1600 365 KB

ShopSabre 1200×1600 365 KB

Haas 1177×717 108 KB

Haas 1177×717 108 KB

#7 We went into the season with the plan to rebuild from the start. V1’s main goal is to win our Week 1 comp. V2’s main goal is to excel at higher levels of play, leveraging our excellent machining capabilities.V2 was originally supposed to have more room to be different, however we ran into time constraints and settled on a upgraded version of V1.

#8

posts.name: Peter Cooper Jr.
posts.cooked:
overclockedfyre:

Where did the name “Gompei and the HERD” come from?

I can try to answer this to the best of my knowledge. I was on 190 in 1999 & 2000, and the name originated sometime during that era.

The standard FIRST team naming scheme at the time that appeared on standings and such, was <sponsor> & <high school> , so 190 was “WPI & Mass. Academy”. You can still see this format in some FIRST database pages, even though nowadays the “Team Nickname” is more common to see and for people to use. Around this time, it was getting to be common for teams to have those kinds of “nicknames” that they used for their own branding. (And this was just after The Great Renumbering, giving teams permanent numbers that they could also now include in their branding.)

So it was decided that 190 should also have some sort of nickname. “Gompei” is the goat mascot of WPI, named after former mascot-goat-keeper Gompei Kuwada . At the time, 190’s robots were all named “Gompei” as well. So the nickname decided upon was “Gompei and the H.E.R.D.”, with “Gompei” being the robot and “the H.E.R.D.” being the team members. “H.E.R.D.” was a fake acronym with no real meaning; we discussed that each time someone asked what it stood for we should give a new random answer.

I think the name was the work of Col. Ken Stafford, who was brought on at that time to help mentor and run the robotics team. He went on to become a professor at WPI and continue to work with the robotics program there for many years. But it may have been a group effort; I’m not entirely sure his was the main contribution but I think it was.

Even though that was the “nickname” used for some things, I feel like the team still primarily referred to itself as “WPI & Mass. Academy” for quite some time, like that’s what would be on the team t-shirts, with “Gompei and the H.E.R.D.” not mentioned there.

strongalex:

#8

Ut oh. I hope I didn’t give away too many secrets.

link_counts.title: Kenneth A. Stafford | Worcester Polytechnic Institute

posts.name: Grant Watson
posts.cooked:
Mactar:

Taking a look at it could you possibly explain how it deploys, I’d assume it has to do with the blue circle in this image

Absolutely! While what you circled plays an integral part in the deploy, it is not what actually releases the arm. We use a 40lb pulling gas spring from Bansbach Easylift (found on McMaster) to maintain downwards tension on the arm. What’s special about these gas shocks is that they are undamped, so the actuation time is extremely fast. Bansbach makes lots of undamped gas springs, however McMaster seems to only stock the pulling variety. We happened to have one of these gently used on hand and knew it would work well for our needs.

What isn’t shown in the CAD is a single bearing bolted into the Vex gear holding back the white hook. When we reel in the spool, this releases the hook dropping the arm down until the white hook hits a standoff acting as the pivot point for the lock you circled. (gif half speed)

This lock has its own set of much weaker springs, and its only purpose is to prevent the arm from folding back up after deploy. This slides down the arm and traps two small plates seen on the arm acting as a hard stop.

Mactar:

I was also wondering what the yellow circle does, is it a pulley for the rope?

Yes. Part of the difficulty of loose string systems is managing string so we can accurately control the end position of the grappling hook without adding sensors that could fail. We could have placed the spool directly there, however this would make consistent wrapping more difficult to control, as well as being less compact. By minimizing the length of loose string and adding this redirector, we keep the DLS/fleet angle fairly constant and can ensure consistent wrapping independent of what happens above the redirector. I believe @jjsessa posted this link back in 2022 on fleet angle which shows how we did these calculations to set our distances/spool size.

This pulley also placed the string in a position that would make the grappling hook want to rise to the top of the cage when tensioned, which came in handy when we made the switch to the bottom mount. Originally this was just a safety feature in case the grappling hook fell.

Mactar:

Finally, I was wondering what your rope path looked like

Outlined here is the rope path; it starts inside the spool where it wraps around an internal drum and is epoxied in place. It then leaves through a hole and exits the spool, feeding between four standoffs, wraps around the re-director, and exits between the top two standoff guides.

After deploy, the exit hole is roughly in line with the string path keeping the drum from accumulating loose string that could walk to bad places. Guide blocks were also installed to ensure the string is only allowed to go onto the spool and can’t be eaten by the gears during the initial loose pull. screenshot_2025-06-19_090709_720 720×612 158 KB

screenshot_2025-06-19_090709_720 720×612 158 KB

screenshot_2025-06-19_090709_720 720×612 158 KB

While stowed, excess string is kept between the four standoffs and placed between two webs in the climber, which ensures the string is not tensioned during the deploy, causing an early release of the grappling hook (explained below). Button head bolts were used on the entire assembly IRL to prevent catching.

Mactar:

how the grappling hook is attached to the entire assembly.

This was something we had to iterate on a bit as the fast deploy causes a violent shock, yet we wanted an easy and passive release of the grappling hook. Initially we used 3 large magnets borrowed from the original upper deploy method, however this did not survive the shock.

The string is tied to this 5-bar over-center linkage (5 links, 5 joints, 1 half joint for you mechanism nerds out there) that is held in an expanded state during the match by a small central spring. img_1361_720 572×720 170 KB

img_1361_720 572×720 170 KB

img_1361_720 572×720 170 KB

These “wings” interface with two billet blocks fixed to the tail, locking the grappling hook. screenshot_2025-06-19_092006_720 720×576 182 KB

screenshot_2025-06-19_092006_720 720×576 182 KB

screenshot_2025-06-19_092006_720 720×576 182 KB

When the gearbox continues to real in string, the string becomes tensioned and pulls this mechanism shut, releasing it from the billet blocks and freeing the grappling hook. screenshot_2025-06-19_092341_720 720×616 180 KB

screenshot_2025-06-19_092341_720 720×616 180 KB

screenshot_2025-06-19_092341_720 720×616 180 KB

The string does not “bottom out” the mechanism and transfers all load through the slot guides and directly into the surrounding plates, relieving the small standoffs and joints.

Overall this gearbox became extremely “swiss-watchy” and to ensure reliability a lot of thought/safeties were dumped into its design we maaay not have needed, but guaranteed its function.

posts.name: Akhil Rao Narahari
posts.cooked:
Anshu:

We got weight

How much weight did you have to save for the algae intake and end effector? What methods did you use to understand how much weight to pull from each subsystem without losing any physical integrity?

Also, how many revisions did it take to get your algae functionality to a good spot and what was the toughest challenge during that process? (We never touched algae so I’m curious.)

posts.name: Alex Fenwick
posts.cooked:
Overall for the Algae Claw and OTB intake, we needed to come up with around 10-15lbs of extra weight. Having V1 already done and weighed, it gave us a really good perspective on how much weight we needed to cut in order to add everything we wanted. Luckily we were able to save quite a bit of weight from the funnel and elevator gearbox, and the elevator carriage, none of which really sacrificed strength (almost 3lb of elevators motors alone lol). We also switched to 3/8" thunder hex almost everywhere which saved a non zero amount for ‘free’.

The main ‘risks’ came from the lightening of the elevator and drive tubes. We originally only had lightened our front & back drive rails, but we needed more weight so we partial depth pocketed the side rails after the robot was put together. We never noticed any issues until Battle cry, where our climber side drive rail was ever so slightly bent. Lightened Side Rail 690×675 180 KB

Lightened Side Rail 690×675 180 KB

Lightened Side Rail 690×675 180 KB

The algae claw took many revisions and lots of lessons learned… the main difficulty came in how much torque we needed to hold it reliably. The claw originally had two x44s, but we ended with a x60 to power the rollers and a larger gear ratio for the claw. We also changed around the geometry of the claw itself, making the “C” shape deeper. We experimented with different wheels, grip tapes, and stall voltages. Not pictured in the CAD is an extra roller on the claw between the wheels, just a 1.25" tube with grip tape on it.

We also ran into a lot of skipping issues once we started manipulating algae, leading to lots of 3d printed ‘idlers’ around the pulleys to keep the belt engaged. Overall, we probably went through around 10-15 different physical iterations of the claw in the week leading up to and during the WPI event (including almost 3 full swaps during the event itself ). Claw Tensioner 968×687 224 KB

Claw Tensioner 968×687 224 KB

Claw Tensioner 968×687 224 KB
